author: EvanP5
body:
Found at least one hole in the JCapital report:

"We had a hard time identifying this expo center but eventually found an IDEX subsidiary that has a mail drop at a 1 mln sqft shopping mall in Qingdao’s Chengyang District. Renovations are news to the companies that operate there. In fact, the shopping mall is in financial distress and is not honoring contracts with people who bought shops there, according to a local news report.2  Neither the manager of the shopping mall nor two store owners we contacted in the center had ever heard of IDEX, any of its subsidiaries or joint ventures, or the EV showroom the company says it opened on May 1."

&#x200B;

The location that they claim is a shopping mall is Fidelity International Business and Trade City, in Qingdao. It also goes by another name, Fuda International Qimao City. The direct translation to english is "Fidelity International Auto Trade City", not a shopping mall.

I found two companies that sell or have sold cars out of that location. One is a wholesaler of cars, the other is in the automobile dealers industry, basically they sell used cars. I can't say if they still are there though.

[https://www.dnb.com/business-directory/company-profiles.qingdao\_fuda\_zhiyuan\_automotive\_sales\_service\_co\_ltd.c64af56a4b92573399906c7543f5fdb3.html](https://www.dnb.com/business-directory/company-profiles.qingdao_fuda_zhiyuan_automotive_sales_service_co_ltd.c64af56a4b92573399906c7543f5fdb3.html)

[https://www.dnb.com/business-directory/company-profiles.qingdao\_cheyixuan\_used\_cars\_co\_ltd.d3203b5dead40a00580799b8af05ba7d.html](https://www.dnb.com/business-directory/company-profiles.qingdao_cheyixuan_used_cars_co_ltd.d3203b5dead40a00580799b8af05ba7d.html)

&#x200B;

Here is the centre on Google Maps, with a photo from 2019:

[https://www.google.com/maps/place/Fuda+International+Business+%26+Trade+City/@36.330897,120.4309407,13z/data=!4m8!1m2!2m1!1sInternational+Trade+City!3m4!1s0x0:0xfa52bed03ec7de41!8m2!3d36.3308969!4d120.4309591](https://www.google.com/maps/place/Fuda+International+Business+%26+Trade+City/@36.330897,120.4309407,13z/data=!4m8!1m2!2m1!1sInternational+Trade+City!3m4!1s0x0:0xfa52bed03ec7de41!8m2!3d36.3308969!4d120.4309591) .

This is the same location shown in the initial announcement from Ideanomics:

[https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/ideanomics-meg-sales-subsidiary-to-open-100-000-square-meters-facility-in-the-city-qingdao-301015506.html](https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/ideanomics-meg-sales-subsidiary-to-open-100-000-square-meters-facility-in-the-city-qingdao-301015506.html)

and the shopped MEG photos are from there too (there's an album of photos here - [http://house.qingdaonews.com/xinloupan/album4768.html](http://house.qingdaonews.com/xinloupan/album4768.html) \- where you can see one of the unaltered photos). The fact that they used shopped images is questionable - were they meant to show what MEG could be with minimal changes to the centre, or were they meant to deceive stockholders?

The company that owns this centre is called Decai Corporation:  [http://www.qddecai.com.cn/BD\_EN/Case\_detail.php?ID=MzM3](http://www.qddecai.com.cn/BD_EN/Case_detail.php?ID=MzM3)

Their company news feed - [http://qddecai.com/BD\_EN/News.php](http://qddecai.com/BD_EN/News.php) \- doesn't have any mention of Ideanomics, MEG, or Qingdao Mobile New Energy Vehicle Sales Co. Ltd. (the MEG subsidiary that's supposed to be operating there), but they also don't have any news listed from 2020, which could make sense considering Covid-19 hit China at the start of the year.

More later...

author: COVID-19Enthusiast
body:
Sounds like you've been making good faith violations and they've let you slide. It's an SEC regulation, not Fidelity.

With a cash account you can purchase stocks using unsettled cash, but if you do so you then cannot sell that stock until the stock itself settles which usually takes 2 business days. People often misinterpret this and think the issue is buying with unsettled funds, that's not an issue, it's the selling that is the problem.

author: techcaleb
body:
1) Robinhood literally changed the industry. They are THE reason why stock trading is now free almost everywhere.  
2) They have had problems in the past, but in general they are pretty good. Other platforms have problems too, but you probably didn't hear about it. Fidelity had accounts that randomly disappeared earlier this year. Where was that in the news? During the same time Robinhood was down on that high volume day this past spring, Fidelity, TD Ameritrade, and several others were down as well, or restricted trades to phone based trades only (which have an additional fee).  
3) This most recent news has nothing to do with Robinhood. As sad as it is, the kid literally committed suicide because he didn't understand how options work, and didn't try to look it up. Also this "kid" was 20 years old. That's still young in the grand scheme of things, but it's plenty old enough to take responsibility for your own actions.

author: melonlord31
body:
To add on to this, investments in index funds are set up through brokerages (e.g. Vanguard, Fidelity, Schwab, etc.)

Index funds are great "set it and forget it" passive investments. They should be the next investments you look into once you have the fundamentals taken care of (paid off all debt/loans, retirement savings accounts setup, rainy day fund, etc).

You can look up a 3-fund portfolio to see which funds to invest in, but it also depends on your risk level. There are a lot of resources out there for this topic, but the [Bogleheads 3-Fund Portfolio](https://www.bogleheads.org/wiki/Three-fund_portfolio) can help you get started.

author: retawx
body: You would first open up a brokerage account. Reputable, low-cost brokers include Vanguard, Fidelity, and Charles Schwab. Once the account has been opened, you then need to fund it by either transferring money electronically from a checking/savings account or by mailing in a check. Finally, you purchase index mutual funds or index ETFs within the brokerage account. I'm sure customer support at the aforementioned companies would be glad to walk you through the process.

author: MyWifesBF
body:
“Fidelity Investments has bought 10% of Norway and Singapore based tanker owner DHT holdings by acquiring 15.4M shares for a total of $92M. Fidelity is not a big investor in shipping and the move indicates it expects tanker freight rates to continue to be strong as tankers are now widely used to both move crude or store it, following record low oil prices in the past two months. Analysts expect similar investments in other big tanker players like Frontline, Scorpio Tankers and Euronav in the near term. DHT operates a fleet of 27 very large crude carriers. (costas.paris#wsj.com)”

#Faith

author: _TheNorseman_
body:
Before you dive in, consider reading a few books on top of the YT videos you’ve watched. *One Up On Wallstreet* by Peter Lynch; *A Random Walk Down Wallstreet* by Burton Malkiel, and *The Intelligent Investor* by Benjamin Graham are all great books to read. Your main weapon, so to speak, will be knowing how to do your own Due Diligence (you’ll see it abbreviated DD on here a lot.) 

When you’re ready to start purchasing stocks, simply open up an account with Fidelity, TD Ameritrade, Vanguard, or the like. I personally use Fidelity, but IIRC TD Ameritrade is better for providing research tools.

author: goinforit24
body: I used fidelity and they let me trade their money on a good faith agreement while the trade is settling. It just means that I cant trade the stock I bought until my trade closes. For example if I sell one share of Tesla for 1,000, then I can trade $1,000 of fidelities money to buy a share of apple, but I cant sell apple to my initial tesla share settles because I technically bought it with fidelities money.

author: eskimoid
body:
I think you are wrong on all three. The two biggest players in the glass industry are Guardian Glass and Cardinal Glass Industries both of which are privately owned. Both of these companies make the float glass, temper it, and then put it in laminated frames. They they sell this glass to companies like JELD that puts it in framesand then sells it to the consumer for residential projects. For larger projects contractors buy this glass to put it in buildings they are building.

PPG doesn't even make glass anymore. They only make paint. Their glass sector looks like it was bought by Vitro and is traded on MXN.

You literally have corning in there. They make specialty glass as in glass that does not go in commercial or residential buildings.

author: eskimoid
body:
I think you are wrong on all three. The two biggest players in the glass industry are Guardian Glass and Cardinal Glass Industries both of which are privately owned. Both of these companies make the float glass, temper it, and then put it in laminated frames. They they sell this glass to companies like JELD that puts it in framesand then sells it to the consumer for residential projects. For larger projects contractors buy this glass to put it in buildings they are building.

PPG doesn't even make glass anymore. They only make paint. Their glass sector looks like it was bought by Vitro and is traded on MXN.

You literally have corning in there. They make specialty glass as in glass that does not go in commercial or residential buildings.

author: kokeboka
body: I used to work in a major music studio in London. The public perception of the worth of music has changed. Anyone can stream nearly anything for free or very cheap subscriptions. 30 years ago you had to spend 10-20 dollars to buy one album, nowadays that seems like an absurdity to the average consumer. Ease of access means there is now a panoply of genres and bands. Artists have bypassed large studios and large labels because technology now allows them to record at home with a little investment in equipment, self-publish and promote their work through sites like bandcamp, soundcloud and social media in general. Labels used to be the great gatekeepers and help fund recording sessions; that's not how the industry works anymore. I love music, but I don't think the future of the industry will be as profitable as it used to be, by a long shot.

author: Tendieheart_Bear
body:
The Stages of Reopening (update):

Week 0 - Excitement - "OMG we're back!!"

Week 1 - Euphoria - "SPY 300+, I heard there's lines at some place!! V-shaped recovery!!"

Week 2 - Realization - "hindsight, lockdowns were stupid. Probably caused more harm than it prevented"

Week 3 - Concern - "okay the lines are shorter now, I participated in going out, it was meh.. it was slow and awkward, maybe it comes back?"

* Most of you are here (now with rioting)

Week 4 - Growing Concern - "These places are empty... How are they going to make it on 25% capacity, assuming they're even seeing that? No one is getting rehired, in fact they'll probably need to let more go."

Week 5 - Full Bear - "Okay, this is slower than I remember 2009 being. I don't think it's bouncing back. SPY levels totally not sustainable, WTF were we thinking!?!"

Week 6 (**New**) - Joining the Poors - "I thought my white collar job was safe, but the company is being more dick now than they were when we were under lockdown.  I think they retained people just to cultivate good PR during the crisis, but are ready to release employees"

author: galivet
body:
A company splits its stock to increase liquidity.

Consider Berkshire Hathaway, with a share price north of $250K. If a shareholder needs to liquidate enough stock to raise $100K, they can't do it without selling more than twice that value of BRK-A. So maybe they'll pick something else to sell instead that's more right-sized for the amount of money they need. Now consider an individual investor with "only" $100K to invest. That person can't buy even one share of BRK-A. In both cases, the high share price discouraged investors from trading the stock -- it inhibits liquidity. If BRK-A did a 3-for-1 stock split then those two investors could work out a trade with each other.

There are three reasons companies don't split stock:

1. They feel it's prestigious to have a high per-share stock price.
2. They prefer having lower liquidity because it causes the population of investors holding your shares to trend toward being wealthier and trading less frequently. That can provide greater stability for the stock price in normal times.
3. Splitting the stock isn't free. It requires you to pay lawyers, publish notifications to shareholders, and so on. Companies prefer not to incur expenses without a clear payoff.

EDIT: I guess I'll also explain why a company might like a more liquid stock. A more liquid stock will track more closely to its true market value. A low-liquidity stock can drop in price very sharply if it's hard for buyers to purchase it. Go back to that investor who needed to raise $100K. Now suppose that guy **ONLY** has BRK-A and he **HAS** to sell it. Because of the high share price, there's a smaller pool of investors who have the money to buy it from him. Desperate seller + small buyer pool means that seller can get screwed. Maybe in desperation he'll sell for $200K instead of the $250K+ the stock is worth... well then the market sees **ALL** of those shares as worth only $200K and the share price plummets. Now of course the price isn't really determined by what one guy does, but in a crisis a lot of sellers can find themselves in the same boat and it can happen.

This kind of liquidity problem is why the US Fed recently started buying up bond ETFs -- desperate sellers + small buyer pool would have put the price of those bonds through the floor *even though the bonds are actually still valuable* had the Fed not stepped in. Because the Fed has the money to buy anything, it can buy those bonds at a normal market price from anyone and let the price decline in a less terrifying way for everyone involved. When analysts talk about the Fed "providing liquidity," this is what they mean.

author: cj17digr
body:
When China sold ~25% of their Treasuries last year or the year before, the treasury cost to borrow went down.

China is ~5% of the market now.  I think you underestimate the amount of Treasuries pension and endowments hold and pour into the market.

If they try to sell too quickly, the Fed will buy the Treasuries to calm the market and slowly sell them to the market.  This is literally a non event.

author: carterbrianw
body:
Hey guys. Made a Reddit account 30 days ago and spend around 3-4 hours a day here. Finally able to post. Crazy stuff happening in the world, people rioting and stuff. Had a smoothie for breakfast then went and got free Popeyes because when I went yesterday they gave me 2 French fries. That’s not an exaggeration, my meal contained two French fries. Like one, two. After that I came home and hung out. Then I went to qdoba, which is significantly better than chipotle. Now I’m just hanging out.

EDIT: sold 3 Tesla calls at 7.15 today. Call me a pussy, but my average was 1.42. Holding 2 $315 AAPL puts

author: moboo
body:
You know how some psychologists have looked at traumatic historical periods and concluded that some people actually acted and felt like they were invincible after a close brush with death? An example would be how many Londoners got more and more cavalier as The Blitz of London went on. This market is like that! If that didn’t do us in, people don’t know what will. 

“Corona didn’t kill me, mate! Nothin’ can touch me now! Me and JPow gunna get right smashed tonight, snort some Tokyo off a stripper’s arse, and then buy more calls come mornin’!”
